spans.text: Raana's post only had one photo, it's more like the sun rising from the west if she could prepare content, although her posting is already halfway there.
The photo she posted has no technique, focusing on the telephone pole next to it, with half of the parking lot and half of the bungalows in the background.
Taki recognizes this place, it's near their high school, not somewhere they go often, but it has some memories.
What is Raana doing posting this early in the morning...?
Taki typed some words in the comment box, then deleted them all in one go.
Oh well... never mind.
A new comment appeared below after the second refresh.
Uh.
Not wanting to at all, really not curious, really just being nosy, Taki clicked into the pink profile picture.
After scrolling a few times meaninglessly, she gently clicked the little red heart.
She thought about it.
Then cancelled it.
She continued to scroll down.
Ah... Tomori also updated yesterday.
Anon's homepage forwarded one of Tomori's posts.
Tomori's posts are usually small animals and small stones, and there are also many novel angles of the lens, detailed and natural, it always makes people feel comfortable to scroll through.

Tomori posted a picture of a potted plant on the windowsill yesterday, the sun shining on the brown soil and fallen leaves, and something seemed to be covered under the fallen leaves, revealing a black corner.
As expected of Tomori...

Taki clicked into Tomori's homepage, she hadn't looked at SNS for a few days, and Tomori's update frequency was not high, only two new posts, one was the one just now, and the other was a picture of a squirrel on the mountain.
She must have gone out with her family, she mentioned it last time.
Scrolling down further are some pictures from offline events. Taki had been to Tomori's autograph session before, but she didn't know much about some recent events.

Taki started browsing everyone's homepage one by one, without any purpose, just emptying her brain and casually looking at everyone's recent situation. Some of the content she had clearly seen, but it felt like the first time she had seen it, unfamiliar and novel.
Tomori's homepage also posts some of her newly created poems and paintings, as well as every gift sent to her by fans, and responses to every letter.
She clicked into Soyo's homepage, the first one was a photo before boarding at the airport. Is this a business trip or a return trip?
Scrolling down further are some exotic delicacies and beautiful scenery. Oh, it's a return trip.
Almost every post of everyone has Anon's comments below, so she couldn't help but click in again.
Among the forwards on the homepage are people she knows, Uika Misumi, and her band.
So she clicked into Umiri's homepage, the latest one was a live house at midnight - outside of Mujica, Umiri still maintains the habit of occasionally supporting other bands.
From Umiri, she found several high school classmates who had a good relationship, and found that one of them had known her university classmate for a long time...
She jumped around aimlessly like this, surprisingly discovering that she knew so many people, and these people intersected each other, forming a huge and intricate social circle.
And she had never noticed it before.
And never been interested.
Before she knew it, a whole morning had passed.
If it were normal, lying down and scrolling through her phone for a whole morning would have made Taki feel like she was going to collapse, but today she had no motivation to do anything.
If the ending is already destined, then what is the point of everything done before?
She was too tired. After finally stopping, all the fatigue that she had left behind chased after her, dragging her towards the swamp of nothingness.
But she was still constantly flipping through the social media of her friends.
Can some kind of vitality that has never been noticed before always attract the dying?
Or is it because she has never really carefully understood the lives of the people around her, and she is starting to regret it now?
These thoughts just flowed quickly along the torrent of the subconscious. Apart from mechanical actions and a barely suspended curiosity, she was unable to think deeply about anything.
"She hates the destined death, so even if she knows the ending is destined, she wants to use these eyes to personally witness another choice..."
Before she knew it, she was watching Anon's recorded broadcast again.
In the recommendation list on the side, are similar commentaries listed by the algorithm or academic videos linked to the theme of death.
One video caught Taki's attention.
From the cover, it can be seen that the video records a long-ago interview, and the title below lists the fact that the interviewee can only live for fourteen weeks.
Similar situations made Taki move her fingers and leave the circle of acquaintances, and clicked into this recording that was far away from her in time and space.
Due to the blurry picture quality, Taki did not initially distinguish which one was the host and which one was the dying patient.
The famous professor, who was said to have an incurable disease, was wearing a well-fitting suit, sitting calmly in the chair, talking to the host about love, death and life.
The sound quality of the video was very poor, and Taki understood it vaguely. She always felt that their conversation was too casual and jumpy, as if it was just an after-dinner chat.
The host praised the professor for his good complexion, but the professor just smiled.
Emily, you know, everyone says that to me... but I know my condition, I even need someone to wipe my butt for me.
But I put on makeup, dress nicely, and then go on TV. That way all of New York will say: Ha, he looks great! He's the best-looking dying person I've ever seen!
There was a burst of laughter from the audience.
Very humorous, Professor.
The next question may be a bit offensive, it's about your recent situation...
Go ahead Emily, if I minded, I wouldn't have come to this studio in the first place.

Thank you for your understanding. I believe there are many people in the world who are in the same situation, but I am afraid that the vast majority of them will not have the smile on your face. How exactly can one have such a mentality?
Everyone knows they are going to die, but no one wants to really believe it. They always feel that this is too far away, too far to be real.
I also know that I am going to die, but I am forced to believe it - honestly, if you don't even believe the guys at Weill Cornell Medical College, you will only be regarded as a stubborn old thing.
There was another soft laughter from the audience.
The day I was forced to believe it, I only had one thought: Am I just going to waste the rest of my time, waiting to go to heaven to see my dear Sophia?
But then I thought: I still have a Kröger Lifetime Achievement Award at the bottom of my pocket - the word "lifetime" will not meet the definition if it is two days short.
Since I am a professor, why can't I treat death as the last lesson? So I started teaching students at home.

I reacquainted myself with many former students, and I talked to them about death, fear, desire, self-pity, forgiveness, life... and found that until I was seventy years old, I had not learned how to live.
But now I have learned how to die. I want to die peacefully, decently, and quietly until the last moment.

I want to teach students until my last breath, and then leave my observations on death as a legacy. I also want to design my epitaph, choose the rock music to play at the funeral, and put graduation caps on the last batch of students...
You see, once you learn how to die, you learn how to live.
So, I'm a busy man now, busier than before I retired, busier than ever.
Seriously Emily, next time you want to ask me out, you might have to call my secretary.
The host and the audience laughed.
However, there was no next interview. The last piece of information in the video indicated that this witty old professor passed away two weeks later.
When she came back to her senses, Taki was already sitting at the table, frantically searching for the professor's works and life on the computer.
But, what's the use, that's someone else after all.
The browser with dozens of tabs open crashed under the burden.
Only then did Taki stop blankly, and then collapsed into the chair as if deflated.
Suddenly, she realized that she was in a familiar posture, at a familiar work desk, sinking into familiar emotions.
How many nights had she been frustrated alone in this small space, and then with a goal in mind, she continued to bury her head and move forward.
The chaotic information gradually settled in her mind, and a distant memory quietly floated to the surface, condensing into shape in her mind.
...When did you start learning to use DTM?
Middle school.
Thinking that maybe it will be useful someday.
Maybe someday.
Every day in the past has been used.
Today too.
And tomorrow.
And tomorrow's tomorrow.
Ha…
The heavy breath melted into the thin, cool air. Taki, like a person who had just regained all her senses, realized that the temperature had dropped sharply as night fell.
(If I can leave any legacy...)
She sat up, leaned in front of the computer, opened the composition software, and created a new project.
This time, she had no lyrics, she was going to start from scratch and build a song that belonged only to her.
And then——
——— Achoo!!!
A sudden sneeze interrupted Taki's surging determination.
(It's cold... is it this cold at night...)
(I'm sleepy, last night... tsk, I didn't sleep last night...)
(Speaking of which, even if I'm composing a new song, I have absolutely no inspiration or material right now...)
Hmm…………
————I want to die peacefully, decently, and quietly until the last moment.
————Once you learn how to die, you learn how to live.
(...That's it for today.)
Taki set the computer to standby and walked out of the room.
She calmly ate something, took a shower, and returned to the bedroom to lie down half an hour later.
As soon as she closed her eyes, countless things she could do flooded into her mind, most of them fleeting, but a few choices remained.
But.
In order to die eight days later, let's go to sleep now.
报幕
